Thought, Ethics, and Politics Beyond the Human (Prof. CÃ³rdova / TTh 10:00-11:15am in person)
Content:  Readings in philosophical and literary texts on "nature" and on the ethics and politics of human-nonhuman relations. How - beyond traditional anthropocentrism - can we respond and be responsible to nonhuman beings? How should we conceive of and care for their strange proximity to us and their undeniable difference? Are these concerns separate from or entangled with issues of social and political justice? And are these questions contemporary - are they generated by the ongoing climate catastrophe and emergent ecological consciousness - or have they been with us for centuries and become, now, only far more urgent? Exploring these and related issues, students will closely study and collectively discuss texts while undertaking assignments ranging from the analytic to the experimental.
course_description: Through a variety of texts and artifacts, including but not restricted to literature, travelogues, legal documents, medical, historical, and political treatises, visual arts, students are introduced to specific interdisciplinary issues in French and Francophone Studies. Taught in English.
